channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: UC makes landmark decision to drop ACT AND SAT requirement for admission
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: UC regents vote to suspend SAT and ACT testing requirements for admission, marking a turning point in the debate over standardized test scores.
item.content:encoded: UC regents vote to suspend SAT and ACT testing requirements for admission, marking a turning point in the debate over standardized test scores.

media:content.media:description: PEMBROKE PINES, FL - MARCH 06: A college applicant uses an SAT Preparation book to study for the test on March 6, 2014 in Pembroke Pines, Florida.

item.title: California lawmakers say state unemployment help still isn't coming fast enough amid coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Legislators criticize the state Employment Development Department, citing phone and computer problems. Agency's director says incoming funding will help.
item.content:encoded: Legislators criticize the state Employment Development Department, citing phone and computer problems. Agency's director says incoming funding will help.

media:content.media:description: California employers added 45,800 jobs in October. The unemployment rate dipped slightly to 10.1% from 10.2%. Above, applicants at a job fair in Concord, Calif.

item.title: Yosemite may reopen in June, with half the number of visitors, ticketed entry
item.dc:creator: Mary Forgione
item.description: Lodgings and some campgrounds would reopen under a draft plan that still requires approval from the state and the feds.
item.content:encoded: Lodgings and some campgrounds would reopen under a draft plan that still requires approval from the state and the feds.

media:content.media:description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, CA - APRIL 11: Yosemite Falls seen without people due to the park closure on April 11, 2020. The trail is empty leading to Yosemite Falls in Yosemite Park due to the closure. Yosemite National Park is closed to visitors due to the coronavirus, Covid 19. Animals roam the park without having to worry about crowds of people. Madera County on Saturday, April 11, 2020 in Yosemite National Park, CA. (Carolyn Cole / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Carolyn Cole/Carolyn Cole/Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times

item.title: 4 arrested during protest over coronavirus restrictions in San Clemente
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: About 100 protesters converged near the pier to demand that stay-at-home rules in California be lifted and San Clemente officials remove fencing enclosing a beach parking lot.
item.content:encoded: About 100 protesters converged near the pier to demand that stay-at-home rules in California be lifted and San Clemente officials remove fencing enclosing a beach parking lot.

media:content.media:description: SAN CLEMENTE, CA -- WEDNESDAY, APRIL 8, 2020: An aerial view of the previously closed San Clemente pier and now closed San Clemente beach, which was closed to help curb the spread of the coronavirus in San Clemente, CA, on April 8, 2020. Officials said the Orange County Sheriff's Department, Marine Safety, Code Enforcement and Park Rangers will increase monitoring and people who do not comply could be cited. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Hollywood Hills land sale makes Griffith Park a bit bigger
item.dc:creator: Jack Flemming
item.description: A community fundraiser recently raised $500,000 to buy two parcels adjacent to Griffith Park, ensuring the land will not be developed.
item.content:encoded: A community fundraiser recently raised $500,000 to buy two parcels adjacent to Griffith Park, ensuring the land will not be developed.

media:content.media:description: Griffith Observatory can be seen from one of the higher trails in the park, which is more than 4,200 acres.
media:content.media:credit: Michael Robinson Chavez / Los Angeles Times

item.title: L.A. County surpasses 2,000 coronavirus deaths: 'A very sad milestone'
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Hannah Fry, Leila Miller, Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: The county's fatalities account for nearly 60% of the COVID-19 deaths in the state, which has recorded more than 3,500 deaths.
item.content:encoded: The county's fatalities account for nearly 60% of the COVID-19 deaths in the state, which has recorded more than 3,500 deaths.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA, Tuesday, May 19, 2020 - People walk, jog and bike past Evergreen Cemetery as local stay at home orders are increasingly relaxed months into the Covid-19 pandemic. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Orange County extends beach hours for Memorial Day weekend, reopens some parking lots
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Seal Beach, Huntington Beach and Newport Beach are now open daily from before sun-up to past dawn. Laguna Beach is keeping stricter weekend times, closing midday.
item.content:encoded: Seal Beach, Huntington Beach and Newport Beach are now open daily from before sun-up to past dawn. Laguna Beach is keeping stricter weekend times, closing midday.

media:content.media:description: SEAL BEACH-CA-MAY 21, 2020: Beach goers enjoy a day at Seal Beach while social distancing on Thursday, May 21, 2020, as the city of Seal Beach extends the hours they are open. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 40 of California's 58 counties get OK for more robust reopening
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Ventura and San Diego counties are among the latest to get state approval to push through Phase 2. Orange County hasn't been given the green light yet, and L.A. County doesn't meet the criteria.
item.content:encoded: Ventura and San Diego counties are among the latest to get state approval to push through Phase 2. Orange County hasn't been given the green light yet, and L.A. County doesn't meet the criteria.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA - MAY 21: Roger Anderson and son Trey, 11, enjoy breakfast served by Nora Nancy at Busy Bee Cafe on Main Street in downtown Ventura Thursday morning as Ventura County has become the largest county in Southern California to resume dine-in service at restaurants and in-store shopping joining a growing list of California counties that have been given permission to enter phase two of reopening after closures due to coronavirus Covid-19. Downtown on Thursday, May 21, 2020 in Ventura, CA. "This is one of our favorite paces to eat so we made a point to swing in." Said Roger. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County achieves major coronavirus win as transmission rate hits lowest level
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: An increasing downturn in the daily number of new cases suggests the transmission number is slightly under 1, a milestone for L.A. County.
item.content:encoded: An increasing downturn in the daily number of new cases suggests the transmission number is slightly under 1, a milestone for L.A. County.

media:content.media:description: CULVER CITY, CA-MAY 14, 2020: Lindsay Rojas, 28, owner of Lindsay's Dog Walks in Culver City, walks Gomez, left, and Nikki, brother and sister Golden Retrievers, on Le Bourget Ave. in Culver City. The dogs belong to an elderly woman named Riya who has multiple sclerosis. During the coronavirus pandemic, experts warn that dogs should not interact with other dogs outside their immediate family. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Online child sex abuse reports surge as kids spend more time on computers amid coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Law enforcement has been overwhelmed by a massive surge in tips about online child sexual abuse and exploitation tied coronavirus at-home learning.
item.content:encoded: Law enforcement has been overwhelmed by a massive surge in tips about online child sexual abuse and exploitation tied coronavirus at-home learning.

media:content.media:description: City Hall reflected on the Los Angeles Police Department headquarters in downtown Los Angeles on Friday, May 3, 2019. (Photo by Nick Agro / For The Times)

item.title: Lori Loughlin always insisted she was innocent in admissions scandal. Why change now?
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Lori Loughlin and husband Mossimo Giannulli's guilty plea announcement marks a major moment in the scandal that rocked American academia.
item.content:encoded: Lori Loughlin and husband Mossimo Giannulli's guilty plea announcement marks a major moment in the scandal that rocked American academia.

media:content.media:description: Actress Lori Loughlin, front, and husband, clothing designer Mossimo Giannulli, rear, depart federal court in Boston on Wednesday, April 3, 2019, after facing charges in a nationwide college admissions bribery scandal. (AP Photo/Charles Krupa)

item.title: Pulling dollar bills off the wall to keep going in rural California
item.dc:creator: Louis Sahagun
item.description: As the coronavirus lockdown severs commerce along the eastern Sierra Nevada range, rural towns look to the future with dread.
item.content:encoded: As the coronavirus lockdown severs commerce along the eastern Sierra Nevada range, rural towns look to the future with dread.

media:content.media:description: LONE PINE, CA - MAY 07: Jake's Saloon owners Sherri Newman, right, and Forrest Newman, left, chat inside the temporarily closed bar on Main St. Thursday, May 7, 2020 in Lone Pine, CA. Newman and employees removed thousands of dollar bills left by customers over the years and divided up the cash as a bonus since the closure has limited their income. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Lori Loughlin to plead guilty in college admissions scandal, faces 2 months in prison
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Lori Loughlin will plead guilty for her role in the college admissions scandal. She faces 2 months in prison.
item.content:encoded: Lori Loughlin will plead guilty for her role in the college admissions scandal. She faces 2 months in prison.

media:content.media:description: Actress Lori Loughlin and husband Mossimo Giannulli exit the Boston Federal Court house after a pre-trial hearing with Magistrate Judge Kelley at the John Joseph Moakley US Courthouse in Boston on Aug. 27, 2019. (Joseph Prezioso/AFP/Getty Images/TNS) ** OUTS - ELSENT, FPG, TCN - OUTS **

item.title: New UC Merced chancellor is a farmworker's son and UC alum
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: Juan Sánchez Muñoz, 53, the son of a Joaquin Valley farmworker, has been named the new chancellor of UC Merced. Muñoz will lead the youngest and most diverse UC campus.
item.content:encoded: Juan Sánchez Muñoz, 53, the son of a Joaquin Valley farmworker, has been named the new chancellor of UC Merced. Muñoz will lead the youngest and most diverse UC campus.

media:content.media:description: Juan Sanchez Munoz has been named new UC Merced chancellor. (UC Merced)

item.title: Coronavirus in Tijuana: Paramedics risk their lives to help the sick
item.dc:creator: Marcus Yam, Ruben Vives
item.description: The coronavirus is killing so many people in Tijuana that the morgue has run out of refrigerator space for bodies.
item.content:encoded: The coronavirus is killing so many people in Tijuana that the morgue has run out of refrigerator space for bodies.

media:content.media:description: TIJUANA, BAJA CALIFORNIA -- WEDNESDAY, APRIL 29, 2020: As Sergio Garcia stands in the doorway to calmly explain the next steps after death, Georgina Barajas Rios, grieves for her mother who just passed away, Maria Ruiz Olmedo, 71, after she suffered from symptoms that match COVID-19 symptoms, at their home, in Tijuana, Mexico, on April 29, 2020. (Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Marcus Yam/Marcus Yam/Marcus Yam/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Lockdowns crippled his 'bouncy house' business. Nearly bankrupt, he's pushing back
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: Jim Edmonds' party rental business was hit when gatherings were restricted to stem the COVID-19 pandemic. With no relief in site, he's turned to protests.
item.content:encoded: Jim Edmonds' party rental business was hit when gatherings were restricted to stem the COVID-19 pandemic. With no relief in site, he's turned to protests.

media:content.media:description: Jim Edmonds runs a bouncey house rental company near Sacramento. The shutdown has driven him close to bankruptcy, pushing him to join rallies at the state capitol. He was arrested at one on May 1, but returned for days later for another. He is pictured here standing at the Capitol, where CHP officers formed a line to keep protesters out.

item.title: California is reopening, but anxious customers are slow to come back
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller, Maura Dolan, Cindy Carcamo
item.description: California is reopening, but anxious customers are slow to come back
item.content:encoded: California is reopening, but anxious customers are slow to come back

media:content.media:description: A deserted restaurant in Yountville

item.title: Skelton: Newsom wise to end one-man rule on coronavirus, giving local leaders more discretion
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: Newsom has wisely relented on his coronavirus restrictions. There's no need to get into the equivalent of a shooting war with rural communities — especially those in the far north, where many people resent being part of California anyway.
item.content:encoded: Newsom has wisely relented on his coronavirus restrictions. There's no need to get into the equivalent of a shooting war with rural communities — especially those in the far north, where many people resent being part of California anyway.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom announces new criteria related to coronavirus hospitalizations and testing that could allow counties to open faster than the state, during a news conference at Mustards Grill in Napa, Calif., Monday May 18, 2020. Newsom says the new criteria could apply to 53 of the state's 58 counties. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool)

item.title: Court orders Koreatown business to stop advertising radish paste as coronavirus treatment
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: A judge forbade a Koreatown business from making any "untrue or misleading statements" about radish paste's ability to cure or prevent the coronavirus or COVID-19.
item.content:encoded: A judge forbade a Koreatown business from making any "untrue or misleading statements" about radish paste's ability to cure or prevent the coronavirus or COVID-19.

media:content.media:description: Mike Feuer

item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: Coronavirus: The percentage of people testing positive has plunged in Riverside County
item.content:encoded: Coronavirus: The percentage of people testing positive has plunged in Riverside County

media:content.media:description: MORENO VALLEY, CA- MAY 6, 2020: Doctors and nurses wave thanks as residents pay tribute to them during a drive-by rally honoring frontline heroes the midst of the coronavirus pandemic at the Emergency Room entrance to Riverside University Health System on May 6, 2020 in Moreno Valley, California. (Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Defying state coronavirus order, a thousand pastors plan to hold in-person services for Pentecost
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: More than 1,200 pastors have signed a 'Declaration of Essentiality,' asserting their churches are as essential as any grocery or hardware store and should be allowed to reopen.
item.content:encoded: More than 1,200 pastors have signed a 'Declaration of Essentiality,' asserting their churches are as essential as any grocery or hardware store and should be allowed to reopen.

media:content.media:description: Wally Thomas of Lake Forest and Denean MacAndrew of Mission Viejo take part in a protest in Huntington Beach on May 9, 2020.

item.title: LAPD names officers who fatally shot man in Harbor Gateway area
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: The Los Angeles Police Department on Wednesday identified three officers involved in the fatal shooting of a man last week as David Orozco, David Torres and Brandon Prisk.
item.content:encoded: The Los Angeles Police Department on Wednesday identified three officers involved in the fatal shooting of a man last week as David Orozco, David Torres and Brandon Prisk.

item.title: As California beaches reopen, seawall construction becomes legislative battleground
item.dc:creator: Rosanna Xia
item.description: A move to streamline construction of seawalls in Orange and San Diego counties would doom public beaches, environmentalists say.
item.content:encoded: A move to streamline construction of seawalls in Orange and San Diego counties would doom public beaches, environmentalists say.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA - JANUARY 10, 2019 High surf pummels Faria Beach homes north of Ventura at sunrise created by storms spreading from the northern pacific sparking dangerous conditions along beaches in Southern California Thursday January 10, 2019. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Irvine police arrest former Marine on weapons charges
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: A 24-year-old former U.S. Marine was arrested on suspicion of possessing illegal firearms on Wednesday.
item.content:encoded: A 24-year-old former U.S. Marine was arrested on suspicion of possessing illegal firearms on Wednesday.

item.title: California's coronavirus relief program for unemployed immigrant workers gets off to a rocky start
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom has launched a program providing $500 to immigrants without legal status who have been put out of work because of the coronavirus pandemic, but several state lawmakers want more.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom has launched a program providing $500 to immigrants without legal status who have been put out of work because of the coronavirus pandemic, but several state lawmakers want more.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses his revised 2019-2020 state budget during a news conference Thursday, May 9, 2019, in Sacramento, Calif. Newsom, a Democrat, has proposed a $213.5 billion a spending plan. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: Orange County coronavirus fatalities nearing 100

item.description: Officials reported 10 new coronavirus-related deaths Wednesday, for a total of 98 among 4,742 cases.
item.content:encoded: Officials reported 10 new coronavirus-related deaths Wednesday, for a total of 98 among 4,742 cases.

media:content.media:description: SAN CLEMENTE, CA - MAY 18: A group of women shield their faces as they walk the San Clemente Pier on Monday, May 18, 2020 in San Clemente, CA. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California prisons to begin accepting inmates as coronavirus deaths mount in Chino
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: After a two-month hold on the intake of new inmates amid the coronavirus pandemic, California's prisons are expected to resume processing next week.
item.content:encoded: After a two-month hold on the intake of new inmates amid the coronavirus pandemic, California's prisons are expected to resume processing next week.

media:content.media:description: Betty Broderick who killed her ex-husband, Daniel T. Broderick III, and his wife, Linda Kolkena Broderick in 1989, asked a parole board to be released at the California Institution for Women Chino on Thursday. (K.C. Alfred/Union-Tribune)

item.title: L.A. sheriff will defy subpoena from oversight commission on jail conditions
item.dc:creator: Cindy Chang
item.description: Los Angeles County Sheriff Alex Villanueva said he refuses to testify before the civilian oversight board on jail safety during the novel coronavirus crisis.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County Sheriff Alex Villanueva said he refuses to testify before the civilian oversight board on jail safety during the novel coronavirus crisis.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Dec. 3, 2018 file photo newly-elected Los Angeles County Sheriff Alex Villanueva speaks during a swearing-in ceremony in Monterey Park, Calif. Villanueva will limit when inmates in the county's jails can be transferred to federal authorities for deportation. Sheriff's Department spokeswoman Nicole Nishida said on Friday, Feb. 15, 2019, the agency will reduce the number of misdemeanor charges that can trigger an inmate's transfer. She could not immediately say which misdemeanor charges would no longer qualify. (AP Photo/Jae C. Hong, File)

item.title: Larry Aubry, black activist icon and 'godfather of South Central Los Angeles,' dies
item.dc:creator: Gale Holland
item.description: The conscience of black L.A., Aubry wrote a column for the Los Angeles Sentinel for 33 years.
item.content:encoded: The conscience of black L.A., Aubry wrote a column for the Los Angeles Sentinel for 33 years.

media:content.media:description: Larry Aubry, 73, is a columnist with the Los Angeles Sentinel and a longtime community activist.

item.title: Despite many coronavirus deaths, Tulare County vows to defy Newsom and further reopen
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, James Rainey
item.description: The Tulare County Board of Supervisors voted to push the county all the way through Phase 3 of California's reopening road map.
item.content:encoded: The Tulare County Board of Supervisors voted to push the county all the way through Phase 3 of California's reopening road map.

media:content.media:description: Yvonne Wright, right, shops for shoes with the help of sales person Jennifer Blythe-Freiner at Brown's Shoe Fit Co., Wednesday, May 20, 2020, in Visalia, Calif. Tulare County's board of supervisors voted 3-2 Tuesday to move further into the state's four-stage reopening plan than is allowed. That means nearly all businesses and churches could reopen, though county officials said businesses should adhere to state guidelines on social distancing and other health measures. (AP Photo/Marcio Jose Sanchez)

item.title: L.A. city and county fight over how to shelter homeless people living near freeways
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes
item.description: A hearing about the moving of homeless people living near freeways was canceled after L.A. city and county couldn't agree to a plan to work together on how to proceed.
item.content:encoded: A hearing about the moving of homeless people living near freeways was canceled after L.A. city and county couldn't agree to a plan to work together on how to proceed.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA MAY 19, 2020-Homeless people line up tents along Figueroa St. under the 101 Freeway in Downtown Los Angeles Tuesday. Thousands of homeless people living near freeways in L.A. County are in line to receive alternative shelter during the COVID-19 pandemic. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Most California school districts plan to open in the fall. Here's how it would work

item.description: Tony Thurmond, California's superintendent of schools, has updated the public on safely reopening schools in the fall.
item.content:encoded: Tony Thurmond, California's superintendent of schools, has updated the public on safely reopening schools in the fall.

item.title: A new high for coronavirus deaths in California as counties push ahead with reopening
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry, Rong-Gong Lin II, Luke Money
item.description: California reported 132 new coronavirus-related fatalities Tuesday — the most in a single day — as counties move forward with plans to reopen.
item.content:encoded: California reported 132 new coronavirus-related fatalities Tuesday — the most in a single day — as counties move forward with plans to reopen.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 18: Alfredo Contreras, left, is getting the oral swab test for coronavirus from Family Nurse Practitioner Anniesatu Newland at walk-in coronavirus testing at St. John's Well Child and Family Center in South Los Angeles, one of the South and Central LA neighborhoods hit hard by coronavirus. South Central on Monday, May 18, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: WWE reacts to the death of former pro wrestler Shad Gaspard
item.dc:creator: Chuck Schilken
item.description: Figures from around the WWE react to the death of former wrestler Shad Gaspard, whose body was found early Wednesday near the Venice Pier.
item.content:encoded: Figures from around the WWE react to the death of former wrestler Shad Gaspard, whose body was found early Wednesday near the Venice Pier.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this July 15, 2013, file photo, professional wrestler Shad Gaspard attens the 8th Annual BTE All-Star Celebrity Kickoff Party at the Playboy Mansion in Beverly Hills, Calif. The Los Angeles Police Department says a body found on Venice Beach early Wednesday, May 20, 2020 is that of former World Wrestling Entertainment pro Shad Gaspard. He went missing in the water while swimming with his son last weekend. (Photo by Paul A. Hebert/Invision/AP, File)

item.title: A big push to reopen restaurants, malls, even gyms ASAP. But it's not that simple
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Kailyn Brown, Sarah Parvini, Charles T. Carter
item.description: New rules will allow restaurant dining rooms and shopping malls to open in counties that meet new criteria.
item.content:encoded: New rules will allow restaurant dining rooms and shopping malls to open in counties that meet new criteria.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA - MAY 19: An aerial view of Bella Terra Mall on Tuesday, May 19, 2020 in Huntington Beach, CA. The day after Gov. Gavin Newsom cracked the door for more counties to potentially lift additional coronavirus-related restrictions, Orange County officials made it clear that they want to get through as quickly as possible. Officials hope to see larger parts of the retail economy - including shopping malls and restaurants - reopen with social distancing restrictions as soon as possible. While health officials said they are still planning how to move further into what the state calls Phase 2, members of the Board of Supervisors said Tuesday that time is of the essence. "We can put together a plan, and I'm still keeping my fingers crossed," said Supervisor Andrew Do. "I'm hoping that by this weekend, we're going to enter Phase 2 fully.(Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Inside the Trump fight with California over opening churches amid coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth, Alex Wigglesworth, Laura Newberry
item.description: The Justice Department warns that stay-at-home measures enacted by California's governor may discriminate against religious groups and violate their rights.
item.content:encoded: The Justice Department warns that stay-at-home measures enacted by California's governor may discriminate against religious groups and violate their rights.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 10: Archbishop Jose Gomez, left, celebrates Good Friday liturgy in a nearly empty Cathedral of Our Lady of the Angels to guard against the coronavirus on Friday, April 10, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Body of former pro wrestler Shad Gaspard found near Venice Pier
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Shad Gaspard, 39, had been missing since Sunday afternoon when he was swept out to sea at Venice Beach. His body was found early Wednesday.
item.content:encoded: Shad Gaspard, 39, had been missing since Sunday afternoon when he was swept out to sea at Venice Beach. His body was found early Wednesday.

media:content.media:description: En foto de archivo del 28 de junio del 2015 Shad Gaspard en la alfombra roja de la premier de Teminator Genisys en Los Ángeles. El 19 de mayo del 2020 el exluchador profesional de la WWE Shad Gaspard sigue desaparecido este martes después de que fue arrastrado por las olas sur de California el fin de semana mientras nadaba con su pequeño hijo. (Photo by Rich Fury/Invision/AP, archivo)

item.title: L.A. Fire Department to inspect vape and smoke shops after downtown explosion
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton, James Queally
item.description: The Los Angeles Fire Department will launch a review of the way vape and tobacco shops store volatile substances after an explosion downtown seriously injured several firefighters.
item.content:encoded: The Los Angeles Fire Department will launch a review of the way vape and tobacco shops store volatile substances after an explosion downtown seriously injured several firefighters.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA-MAY 18, 2020. Members of the Los Angeles Fire Department investigate the scene of a fiery explosion on Boyd St. in the downtown los Angeles Toy District that injured 12 firefighters and damaged buildings and fire equipment, authorities said. The explosion happened around 6:30 pm Saturday, when firefighters responded to the initial call of a fire in the single-story building at 327 Boyd St., between Third and Fourth Streets. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times

item.title: ICE said a 74-year-old was too dangerous to release. He died of apparent suicide

item.description: Choung Woong Ahn's family said he should be released because of his age and health issues. ICE disagreed.
item.content:encoded: Choung Woong Ahn's family said he should be released because of his age and health issues. ICE disagreed.

item.title: Here's a closer look at the ex-deputy mayor enmeshed in City Hall corruption probe
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes, Joel Rubin
item.description: Prosecutors alleged that a deputy mayor was paid by a real estate consultant to help shepherd a major project through L.A. City Hall — and leveraged his power as a city official to aid the development.
item.content:encoded: Prosecutors alleged that a deputy mayor was paid by a real estate consultant to help shepherd a major project through L.A. City Hall — and leveraged his power as a city official to aid the development.

media:content.media:description: Raymond Chan, left, and Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti

item.title: California is finally making progress in the coronavirus battle, even as deaths keep rising
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Iris Lee, Sean Greene
item.description: Three months into California's battle with the coronavirus, there are growing signs that the outbreak is ebbing even as the state death toll continues to climb past 3,400.
item.content:encoded: Three months into California's battle with the coronavirus, there are growing signs that the outbreak is ebbing even as the state death toll continues to climb past 3,400.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 18: Destiny VanSciner, 32, left, is getting the oral swab test for coronavirus from Family Nurse Practitioner Anniesatu Newland at walk-in coronavirus testing at St. John's Well Child and Family Center in South Los Angeles, one of the South and Central LA neighborhoods hit hard by coronavirus. South Central on Monday, May 18, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: I got tested for COVID-19. Should you?
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: L.A. County has made free testing available to anyone who wants it, symptoms or not. Is that good public policy?
item.content:encoded: L.A. County has made free testing available to anyone who wants it, symptoms or not. Is that good public policy?

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA-MARCH 26, 2020: Members of the Los Angeles Fire Dept. wear protective gear while handing out kits to people to swab the inside of their mouths to test for the coronavirus, inside a parking lot on Stadium Way, near Dodger Stadium. Cars in background are drivers, waiting in what was over a 2 hour line, by appointment only to be tested. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. is uneasy about order to move homeless people from freeways. 'There's ethical issues'
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes, David Zahniser
item.description: A federal judge has ordered L.A. to move homeless people away from freeways. Mayor Garcetti says he worries it will lead to confrontations with police.
item.content:encoded: A federal judge has ordered L.A. to move homeless people away from freeways. Mayor Garcetti says he worries it will lead to confrontations with police.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA MAY 19, 2020-A man walks by a homeless encampment on Venice Blvd. under the 405 Freeway in Los Angeles Tuesday. Thousands of homeless people living near freeways in L.A. County are in line to receive alternative shelter during the COVID-19 pandemic. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Listen to the new L.A. Times podcast 'It Was Simple: The Betty Broderick Murders'
item.dc:creator: Patt Morrison
item.description: 'It Was Simple: The Betty Broderick Murders' is a podcast hosted by columnist and reporter Patt Morrison.
item.content:encoded: 'It Was Simple: The Betty Broderick Murders' is a podcast hosted by columnist and reporter Patt Morrison.

item.title: L.A. Surge Hospital for COVID-19 patients to close by the end of June
item.dc:creator: Thomas Curwen
item.description: The surge in coronavirus patients never arrived, so L.A. Surge Hospital will close in June.
item.content:encoded: The surge in coronavirus patients never arrived, so L.A. Surge Hospital will close in June.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 13: St. Vincent Medical Center located at 2131 West 3rd st. in Los Angeles is back in business to help ease the pressure on local hospitals amid the novel coronavirus pandemic. Staff set up beds and other equipment ready to receive patients with Covid-19 starting Monday. The 266-bed facility will serve as a hospital accepting patients that have tested positive at a different regional hospital that may be at capacity. Los Angeles on Monday, April 13, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Celebrity tattoo artist charged with YouTube star's death in crash
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Los Angeles County prosecutors charged Daniel Silva, a celebrity tattoo artist, with the murder of Corey La Barrie, a YouTube personality who died in a crash earlier this month in Valley Village.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County prosecutors charged Daniel Silva, a celebrity tattoo artist, with the murder of Corey La Barrie, a YouTube personality who died in a crash earlier this month in Valley Village.

item.title: L.A. pet grooming services, car washes can reopen, Garcetti says
item.dc:creator: Sarah Parvini
item.description: L.A. pet grooming services, car washes can reopen, Garcetti says
item.content:encoded: L.A. pet grooming services, car washes can reopen, Garcetti says

media:content.media:description: Hertz and Enterprise are both cutting back on the water used to wash their rental fleets.

item.title: Justice Department warns California coronavirus rules may violate religious freedoms
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth, Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: In a letter to the governor, the Justice Department said state coronavirus rules led to the "unequal treatment of faith communities."
item.content:encoded: In a letter to the governor, the Justice Department said state coronavirus rules led to the "unequal treatment of faith communities."

media:content.media:description: California Lt. Gov. Gavin Newsom, pictured at a forum in April, will announce a new ballot initiative to strengthen the state's gun laws on Thursday.

item.title: UC becomes nation's largest university to divest fully from fossil fuels
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: The University of California has fully divested from all fossil fuels, the nation's largest university to do so as pressure grows at Harvard, Stanford and other campuses to join the fight against climate change.
item.content:encoded: The University of California has fully divested from all fossil fuels, the nation's largest university to do so as pressure grows at Harvard, Stanford and other campuses to join the fight against climate change.

media:content.media:description: INYO COUNTY, CA - SEPTEMBER 20, 2017: UC Davis biologist Brian Smithers researches the world-famous 5,000-year-old bristlecone pine forests in the White Mountains west of the Owens Valley community of Big Pine. He said the trees have stopped regenerating, and their lofty, alpine domain is being invaded by pines usually found at warmer, lower elevations. Climate change has made it easier for Limber pine seeds carried to higher elevations by birds to thrive in the Inyo National Forest on September 20, 2017 in Inyo County, California.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Orange County hopes to open malls, restaurants, other retail soon
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: One supervisor said he was hoping that by this weekend, the county could enter Phase 2 of the state's plan for reopening fully.
item.content:encoded: One supervisor said he was hoping that by this weekend, the county could enter Phase 2 of the state's plan for reopening fully.

media:content.media:description: SAN CLEMENTE, CA - MAY 18: Families practice social distancing while playing in the water and sand near the San Clemente Pier on Monday, May 18, 2020 in San Clemente, CA. Orange County beaches are currently open for active recreation, which includes swimming, surfing, and running. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Orange County coronavirus case count reaches 4,500, with no new deaths
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The county's death toll from COVID-19 remained unchanged at 88 Tuesday. The total includes 23 fatalities among residents of nursing facilities.
item.content:encoded: The county's death toll from COVID-19 remained unchanged at 88 Tuesday. The total includes 23 fatalities among residents of nursing facilities.

media:content.media:description: SAN CLEMENTE, CA - MAY 18: Jocelyn Corado, 8, waits for the next set of waves to knock her over near the San Clemente Pier on Monday, May 18, 2020 in San Clemente, CA. Orange County beaches are currently open for active recreation, which includes swimming, surfing, and running. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County aims to reopen by July 4, but must rely on data and science, official warns
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Rong-Gong Lin II, Sarah Parvini
item.description: The goal to more fully reopen in the next six weeks comes as Los Angeles County reports 76 new deaths related to COVID-19 and more than 1,100 new cases.
item.content:encoded: The goal to more fully reopen in the next six weeks comes as Los Angeles County reports 76 new deaths related to COVID-19 and more than 1,100 new cases.

media:content.media:description: PASADENA, CA - MAY 18, 2020: Health care works speak with drivers at the drive thru coronavirus testing site in parking lot B of the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, CA on Monday, May 18, 2020. The coronavirus infection rates are going down in California however the infection rate has not deceased enough. (Francine Orr/ Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Junior lifeguard programs canceled in Los Angeles County, Seal Beach
item.dc:creator: Priscella Vega
item.description: Long Beach, Huntington Beach, Newport Beach and San Clemente are still waiting to see whether the program is feasible amid the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Long Beach, Huntington Beach, Newport Beach and San Clemente are still waiting to see whether the program is feasible amid the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: A San Diego Junior Lifeguards intern lands in the water after jumping off the Ocean Beach Municipal Pier at the end of their four week summer training on Monday, August 13, 2018. Parents and the public were also invited to pay a fee and make the leap with proceeds going to the Prevent Drowning Foundation of San Diego. (Photo by K.C. Alfred/San Diego Union-Tribune)

item.title: With restaurants hurting, cities look to turn streets into dining rooms
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: A proposal would 'open up more public spaces for outdoor dining, transit access and economic activity, with safe physical distancing,' the mayor says.
item.content:encoded: A proposal would 'open up more public spaces for outdoor dining, transit access and economic activity, with safe physical distancing,' the mayor says.

media:content.media:description: LONG BEACH , CALIF. - MAY 7, 2020. A woman wearing a protective mask walks past a shuittered business in Long Beach on Thursday, May 7, 2020. Some non-essential businesses will be allowed to reopen on Friday, May 8, 2020, under California Gov. Gavin Newsom's orders easing coronavirus restrictions on florists, music stores, bookstores and other retailers. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Earthquake: 4.2 quake hits near Fortuna, Calif.
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: The earthquake occurred 27 miles from Eureka, 34 miles from Arcata and 39 miles from McKinleyville.
item.content:encoded: The earthquake occurred 27 miles from Eureka, 34 miles from Arcata and 39 miles from McKinleyville.

media:content.media:description: A magnitude 4.2 earthquake was reported May 19 at 8:58 a.m. 22 miles from Fortuna, Calif.

item.title: California is rapidly speeding up the reopening of the economy. Here's what it means
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna, Phil Willon, Maura Dolan, John Myers
item.description: Counties no longer will be kept from loosening the shutdown rules if they have recorded COVID-19 deaths in the previous two weeks.
item.content:encoded: Counties no longer will be kept from loosening the shutdown rules if they have recorded COVID-19 deaths in the previous two weeks.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA-MAY 18, 2020: Lori Rand of West Los Angeles, left, tries on a ring while being helped by Mary Perez, a salesperson at High Class Jewels on Broadway in downtown Los Angeles. The jewelry store re-opened over the weekend after being forced to previously close due to the coronavirus outbreak. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. children are battling a new syndrome linked to coronavirus. Here's what we know
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: L.A. County is investigating cases of children diagnosed with a rare inflammatory disease who've also tested positive for COVID-19.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County is investigating cases of children diagnosed with a rare inflammatory disease who've also tested positive for COVID-19.

media:content.media:description: In this 2020 photo provided by Amber Dean 9-year-old Bobby Dean lies on a hospital bed in Rochester, N.Y., after being admitted with severe dehydration, abdominal pain and a racing heart. He tested positive for coronavirus at the hospital and the doctors diagnosed him with a pediatric inflammatory syndrome related to the virus. After six days in the hospital, he was able to go home on Mothers Day. (Dean Family Photo via AP)

item.title: Did you check your lottery ticket? Winner hasn't claimed $28-million prize yet
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: A SuperLotto Plus ticket matching all five numbers plus the Mega number was sold in National City, Calif. The winner has 180 days to claim the prize.
item.content:encoded: A SuperLotto Plus ticket matching all five numbers plus the Mega number was sold in National City, Calif. The winner has 180 days to claim the prize.

media:content.media:description: A customer picks up her California Powerball lottery tickets at the famous Bluebird Liquor store in Hawthorne.

item.description: Police were called to an illegal party in violation of the stay-at-home order and while there, encountered a man who shot himself in the groin.
item.content:encoded: Police were called to an illegal party in violation of the stay-at-home order and while there, encountered a man who shot himself in the groin.

item.title: California leased 15,000 hotel rooms to help homeless people. Half sit empty
item.dc:creator: Doug Smith, Benjamin Oreskes
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom's goal was to lease 15,000 hotel rooms to house homeless people vulnerable to the coronavirus. But only half are occupied, records show.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom's goal was to lease 15,000 hotel rooms to house homeless people vulnerable to the coronavirus. But only half are occupied, records show.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 06: Omar Spry of Los Angeles Housing Community Investment Department, pushes a cart of residents' bags into a West L.A. hotel that has been turned into housing for the homeless during the coronavirus pandemic. The homeless housing is through a program with the Hotel Assn. of Los Angeles, Los Angeles County, city of Los Angeles and non-profits. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Photos: Vintage car racing brings sports back to California amid coronavirus restrictions

item.content:encoded: The Vintage Auto Racing Assn. held the races over the weekend as California slowly reopens after coronavirus shutdowns.

The Vintage Auto Racing Association held the races over the weekend as California tries to come out of the Coronavirus lock down. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

They are all wearing protective masks to guard against the coronavirus. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: Undocumented Californians can begin applying for disaster assistance payments of $500 per person and up to $1,000 per household.

media:content.media:description: California Lt. Gov. Gavin Newsom, seen in April, criticized Donald Trump's immigration plan. "Trump's plan will be a disaster and I'll debate that at any time," Newsom said. (Nick Ut / Associated Press)

item.title: 3 Southern California men abducted, 2 killed, in cross-border kidnappings
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth

item.content:encoded: Three Southern California men were abducted, and two killed, by a Tijuana-based kidnapping ring, federal authorities said.

media:content.media:description: A cross-border pedestrian bridge connects the international airport in Tijuana to San Diego (at right). The new access began operations this month.

item.title: After widespread glitches in online AP testing, students can now submit by email
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: After widespread technological glitches prevented scores of students from submitting online AP tests last week, the College Board has rolled out a new safeguard, allowing them to send their completed exams by email beginning Monday.
item.content:encoded: After widespread technological glitches prevented scores of students from submitting online AP tests last week, the College Board has rolled out a new safeguard, allowing them to send their completed exams by email beginning Monday.

media:content.media:description: Students at El Rancho High School in Pico Rivera are seen taking a mid-term AP U.S. Government test.

item.title: Napolitano and UC chancellors will take a 10% pay cut amid coronavirus-related budget crisis
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: University of California President Janet Napolitano and 10 campus chancellors will take a 10% pay cut amid a budget crisis triggered by the coronavirus crisis. The UC chief also announced a systemwide salary freeze for nonunionized employees.
item.content:encoded: University of California President Janet Napolitano and 10 campus chancellors will take a 10% pay cut amid a budget crisis triggered by the coronavirus crisis. The UC chief also announced a systemwide salary freeze for nonunionized employees.

media:content.media:description: WESTWOOD, CA - MARCH 13, 2019 ? UC President Janet Napolitano speaks on the issue of the college bribery scandal during the Regents meeting at UCLA in Westwood on March 13, 2019. Napolitano said they need to look at the admissions process at UC universities. A UCLA men's soccer coach was put on leave for being involved in the bribery scandal. Only two students mentioned the scandal during the open session of the meeting. Most students at the meeting were there to protest tuition increase and fair pay for workers throughout the UC campuses. (Genaro Molina/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 4 children with rare inflammatory disease test positive for coronavirus; 21 under investigation
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Four children in Los Angeles County who have been diagnosed with a rare inflammatory disease known as MIS-C or PIMS have tested positive for COVID-19 through antibody testing. The county is investigating an additional 21 possible cases.
item.content:encoded: Four children in Los Angeles County who have been diagnosed with a rare inflammatory disease known as MIS-C or PIMS have tested positive for COVID-19 through antibody testing. The county is investigating an additional 21 possible cases.

media:content.media:description: At a drive up testing site, Covid Clinic medical assistant Jennifer Quinlan collects a sample for Coronavirus COVID-19 testing at the San Elijo campus of Mira Costa College on April 15, 2020 in Cardiff, California.
media:content.media:credit: Eduardo Contreras/Eduardo Contreras/The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: Officials alarmed by crowds at Malibu beaches, some local parks, warning of dangers
item.dc:creator: Melissa Gomez
item.description: Officials alarmed by crowds at Malibu beaches, some local parks, warning of dangers
item.content:encoded: Officials alarmed by crowds at Malibu beaches, some local parks, warning of dangers

media:content.media:description: MALIBU, CA - MAY 13: Surfers take advantage of the low tide swell at Malibu Surfrider Beach next to the Malibu Pier Wednesday morning as Los Angeles County Beaches reopened for active use only. The beaches have been closed for two months due to the coronavirus Covid-19 pandemic and remained off limits even as the coastline reopened for active use in Orange County. Beachgoers will have to wear masks and maintain a six-foot buffer between themselves and others under continued social distancing requirements. Parking lots, piers and boardwalks will remain closed. Malibu Pier on Wednesday, May 13, 2020 in Malibu, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California records 80,000 coronavirus cases, more than 3,200 deaths
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Though the numbers continue to rise overall, the case count has begun tapering off in some areas as more parts of the state are given the green light to more reopen fully.
item.content:encoded: Though the numbers continue to rise overall, the case count has begun tapering off in some areas as more parts of the state are given the green light to more reopen fully.

media:content.media:description: PLACENTIA, CA - MAY 16: Jim Rafferty, owner of one of Orange County's best-known sports bars Kelly's Korner grabs a beverage for a customer to take out on Saturday, May 16, 2020 in Placentia, CA. The sports bar is effectively grounded as the pandemic shutdowns affect restaurants and limit him to take-out. Like most restaurants and bars, Kelly's has had to pivot drastically to survive. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.content:encoded: Bay Area health officers see enough positives signs in Santa Clara County to move onto Phase 2 of California's reopening plan.

media:content.media:description: SAN JOSE, CALIFORNIA - FEBRUARY 28, 2020: Dr. Sara Cody, Health Officer and Director County of Santa Clara Public Health Department, spoke to journalists about the third case of COVID-19 virus in Santa Clara County which isnt related to any other cases, and emphasized practical measures to be taken to reduce widespread community transmission, at Santa Clara Valley Medical Center in San Jose, California on Friday February 28, 2020. (Photo by Melina Mara/The Washington Post via Getty Images)
media:content.media:credit: The Washington Post/The Washington Post via Getty Im

item.title: Five teenagers shot inside Bakersfield apartment
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Authorities declined to say whether the victims, all of whom were in stable condition at the hospital, lived together or were gathering in the residence.
item.content:encoded: Authorities declined to say whether the victims, all of whom were in stable condition at the hospital, lived together or were gathering in the residence.

media:content.media:description: Bakersfield Police Department investigate a shooting that took place in east Bakersfield, Calif. on Monday, May 18, 2020. Five teenagers were shot and wounded when someone fired into a Southern California apartment early Monday, authorities said. The victims were three 17-year-olds and two 18-year-olds who were hospitalized with moderate injuries, said Bakersfield Police. (Alex Horvath/The Bakersfield Californian via AP)

The new requirements for wearing face masks in Los Angels began Monday at LAX and on local public transit. LAX on Monday, May 11, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Swimmer still missing after lifeguards rescue 10-year-old off Venice Beach

item.title: May showers sprinkle Southern California
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Most areas of Los Angeles County will see a quarter-inch or less of rain, which rarely falls at all this time of year, according to the National Weather Service.
item.content:encoded: Most areas of Los Angeles County will see a quarter-inch or less of rain, which rarely falls at all this time of year, according to the National Weather Service.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 18: Blanca Torres wears her face mask and umbrella in downtown Los Angeles Monday morning as rain douses the southland today amid a cooling trend. National Weather Service meteorologist Kristen Stewart said the rain and falling temperatures are the product of a cold front spawned by a low-pressure system off Northern California and temps are expected to be several degrees lower than last week's. Downtown on Monday, May 18, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Olvera Street merchants struggle to survive amid the coronavirus pandemic
item.dc:creator: Ruben Vives
item.description: The economic hardship caused by the coronavirus pandemic is threatening the future of Olvera Street. Stay-at-home orders prevent people from gathering at the plaza.
item.content:encoded: The economic hardship caused by the coronavirus pandemic is threatening the future of Olvera Street. Stay-at-home orders prevent people from gathering at the plaza.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 13, 2020 - - "We're talking about no business," said Guillermo Garcia, 61, as he looks back at an empty and shuttered Olvera Street in El Pueblo de Los Angeles on May 13, 2020. Garcia owns the restaurant, La Noche Buena," and the store, "Memo's Place," on Olvera Street and has worked there for the past 48 years. His restaurant La Noche Buena is still open for take-out. Merchants on the historic street are currently unable to operate and do not now when they'll be able to reopen. They're asking the city for rent forgiveness between April through the city's final phase of reopening, including six months after that so that they can get back up on their feet. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 10-year-old boy killed in car-to-car shooting in La Puente
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The child was shot in the chest about 9:40 p.m. Sunday while riding in a vehicle, the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department said.
item.content:encoded: The child was shot in the chest about 9:40 p.m. Sunday while riding in a vehicle, the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department said.

media:content.media:description: A 10-year-old boy was shot and killed while riding in a car in La Puente on Sunday night, according to authorities.

item.title: As California reopens, officials hope social distancing prevents new coronavirus outbreaks
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Christopher Goffard, Susanne Rust, Rong-Gong Lin II, Maura Dolan
item.description: At least three Bay Area counties — San Francisco, San Mateo and Marin — plan to ease social distancing rules amid the coronavirus starting Monday.
item.content:encoded: At least three Bay Area counties — San Francisco, San Mateo and Marin — plan to ease social distancing rules amid the coronavirus starting Monday.

media:content.media:description: SAN FRANCISCO, CA - MAY 15: Beverly Weinkauf at Toujours Lingerie jots down notes as she listens to a customer's voicemail on Friday, May 15, 2020, in San Francisco, Calif. Weinkauf, who owns the Fillmore district shop, prepared the shop with her goddaughter Katie Reisman to open on Monday after almost two months of shutdown orders due to the coronavirus pandemic. San Francisco on Monday will lift shutdown orders, allowing curbside pickups. (Santiago Mejia/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images)
media:content.media:credit: San Francisco Chronicle/Hearst N/Hearst Newspapers via Getty Imag

item.title: Column: Filipino nurses battled discrimination to work in American hospitals. Now they fight for PPE
item.dc:creator: Frank Shyong
item.description: Filipino nurses and caregivers, who've played a crucial role in U.S. history, are facing a new battle: getting personal protective equipment during the pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Filipino nurses and caregivers, who've played a crucial role in U.S. history, are facing a new battle: getting personal protective equipment during the pandemic.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA- MAY 16, 2020: After working a 12-hour nursing shift and fresh from a hot shower, Justin Foronda, second from left, has dinner with his mom Lina, left, brother Anthony and Anthony's girlfriend Michelle Diaz during the coronavirus pandemic on May 16, 2020 in Los Angeles, California. Foronda is also a chef at Hifi Kitchen which feeds hospitals. He lives with his mom, who's lab tech and his brother Anthony. (Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Fire and police investigators work to determine cause of downtown explosion that injured 12
item.dc:creator: Hailey Branson-Potts, Richard Winton, Liam Dillon
item.description: A criminal investigation is underway after the warehouse explosion in downtown Los Angeles that injured 12 firefighters and left several buildings damaged, law enforcement sources said.
item.content:encoded: A criminal investigation is underway after the warehouse explosion in downtown Los Angeles that injured 12 firefighters and left several buildings damaged, law enforcement sources said.

media:content.media:description: Firefighters battle a fire at the scene of a commercial fire at 327 E. Boyd St. downtown that has injured about 10 firefighters and left multiple buildings on fire.
media:content.media:credit: Gary Coronado/Los Angeles Times/Gary Coronado/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Earthquake: Magnitude 4.7 quake hits near Eureka, Calif.
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: A magnitude 4.7 earthquake was reported Sunday at 11:55 p.m. 177 miles from Eureka, Calif., according to NOAA's Tsunami Warning System.
item.content:encoded: A magnitude 4.7 earthquake was reported Sunday at 11:55 p.m. 177 miles from Eureka, Calif., according to NOAA's Tsunami Warning System.

item.title: Skelton: To balance California's budget, state will stick it to its most vulnerable citizens
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: 1.2 million Californians who are aged, blind or disabled and clinging to government benefits — take a hit in Governor Gavin Newsom's revised state budget.
item.content:encoded: 1.2 million Californians who are aged, blind or disabled and clinging to government benefits — take a hit in Governor Gavin Newsom's revised state budget.

media:content.media:description: California Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses his revised 2020-2021 state budget during a news conference in Sacramento, Calif., Thursday, May 14, 2020. Reflecting the financial hit California is already seeing from the coronavirus, Newsom proposed cutting $6.1 billion from a variety programs in a state budget he says prioritizes public education, public health and public safety. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool)

item.title: Coronavirus may have spread at a church service. Now the pastor is speaking out
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: Pastor of church where 180 were exposed to coronavirus at Mother's Day service explains what happened
item.content:encoded: Pastor of church where 180 were exposed to coronavirus at Mother's Day service explains what happened

item.title: Officials mishandled coronavirus outbreaks at Lompoc and Terminal Island prisons, lawsuits claim
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: The ACLU filed two class action lawsuits on behalf of prisoners at Lompoc and Terminal Island, claiming officials mishandled coronavirus outbreaks.
item.content:encoded: The ACLU filed two class action lawsuits on behalf of prisoners at Lompoc and Terminal Island, claiming officials mishandled coronavirus outbreaks.

media:content.media:description: SAN PEDRO, CA -- TUESDAY, MAY 12, 2020: A view of the Federal Correctional Institute Terminal Island in San Pedro, CA, on May 12, 2020. Rep. Nanette Diaz Barragan toured the FCI Terminal Island site to inquire about the ``extremely high'' number of COVID-19 cases among inmates and prison staff and about the steps being taken to address them. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County public health officials reported 694 new cases of the coronavirus and 29 related deaths Sunday.

item.title: Criminal probe launched into L.A. building explosion amid questions about stored oils
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton, Hailey Branson-Potts, Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: After a building explosion in downtown L.A. injured 11 firefighters, federal and local officials have launched a criminal probe.
item.content:encoded: After a building explosion in downtown L.A. injured 11 firefighters, federal and local officials have launched a criminal probe.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -- MAY 16: Firefighters first received a call about 6:30 p.m. about a structure fire in the 300 block of Boyd Street south of Little Tokyo, said Erik Scott, a spokesman for the Los Angeles Fire Department, in downtown on Saturday, May 16, 2020, in Los Angeles, CA. The fire left 11 firefighters injured, authorities said. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Raging house party amid coronavirus ends when man shoots himself in the groin, police say
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Despite the coronavirus, there was a raucous house party in the Hollywood Hills. It ended when a man shot himself in the groin, police say.
item.content:encoded: Despite the coronavirus, there was a raucous house party in the Hollywood Hills. It ended when a man shot himself in the groin, police say.
